company.name: Lisa Frank, Inc.
company.address: 6760 S. Lisa Frank Ave., Tucson, Arizona 85706
company.business_description: Lisa Frank, Inc. operates www.lisafrank.com, a website that advertises and sells products to girls, including girls' toys, school supplies, and similar items throughout the United States.

case_info.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)

complaint.factual_background: Lisa Frank, Inc. operated a website directed to children that collected personal information from children under 13 without obtaining parental consent as required by COPPA. The website allowed children to register by providing personal information including names, addresses, email, phone numbers, and birth dates to access shopping features. Despite having a privacy policy stating that parental consent would be required for children 13 or younger, the company did not actually obtain such consent before collecting children's information.

representations_made.description: Claimed that children 13 years or younger would require parental consent before being able to register and participate in e-commerce areas
representations_made.quoted_text: In order to participate in certain areas of our Web site, such as . . .e-commerce, users are required to register and obtain a screen name ("User-ID"). Children 13 years or younger will require parental consent before being able to register and participate . . .

representations_made.description: Claimed that when a child 13 years or younger registers, their parent or guardian would be required to fill out and sign a registration form
representations_made.quoted_text: In the areas that require registration, all registrants receive e-mail confirming their registration. In addition, when a guest 13 years or younger registers, his/her parent or guardian will be required to fill out and sign a registration form. . .

counts.title: False Representation About Parental Consent
counts.representation: Defendant represented in its privacy policy that it would obtain parental consent before permitting visitors under the age of 13 to complete the registration form
counts.fact: Defendant did not obtain parental consent before permitting visitors under the age of 13 to complete the registration form
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in paragraph 26 was false and misleading.

definitions.Rule: the Federal Trade Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312, or as the Rule may hereafter be amended.
definitions.child, collects, collection, Commission,: defined as those terms are defined Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.defendant: Lisa Frank, Inc. and its officers, successors and assigns, agents, representatives, and employees.

provisions.title: Injunction Against Violating COPPA Rule
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the Federal Trade Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule.

requirements.description: Must not violate any provision of the COPPA Rule
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant, its successors and assigns, and its officers, agents, servants, employees and attorneys, and all persons in active concert or participation with any one or more of them who receive actual notice of this Consent Decree by personal service or otherwise, are hereby enjoined from violating, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, website, or other device, any provision of the Rule.

provisions.title: Injunction Against Privacy Policy Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from failing to comply with any representations made in privacy policies about the collection, use, or disclosure of children's personal information, or about procedures to maintain confidentiality, security, or integrity of children's personal information.

requirements.description: Must not fail to comply with privacy policy representations about children's personal information
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant, its successors and assigns, and its officers, agents, servants, employees and attorneys, and all persons in active concert or participation with any one or more of them who receive actual notice of this Consent Decree by personal service or otherwise, are hereby enjoined, in connection with the operation of any website or other online service, from failing to comply with any representation, in the website's privacy policy or elsewhere, about the website's collection, use or disclosure of children's personal information, or about the website's procedures to maintain the confidentiality, security, or integrity of children's personal information.

provisions.title: Consumer Education Remedy
provisions.summary: For five years, defendant must place a clear and conspicuous notice with a hyperlink to FTC's children's privacy website in its privacy policy and in direct notices to parents.

requirements.description: Place FTC children's privacy notice in privacy policy and parent notices for 5 years
requirements.quoted_text: For a period of five (5) years from the date of entry of this Consent Decree, defendant, and its successors and assigns, shall place a clear and conspicuous notice (1) within the privacy policy required to be posted on its website(s) by Section 312.4(b) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(b); and (2) within the direct privacy notice required to be sent to parents by Section 312.4(c) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(c); which states as follows in bold typeface: NOTICE: Visit www.ftc.gov/kidzprivacy for information from the Federal Trade Commission about protecting children's privacy online.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Payment
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a civil penalty of thirty thousand dollars to the United States.

requirements.quoted_text: Defendant shall pay to plaintiff a civil penalty, pursuant to Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(m)(1)(A), in the amount of Thirty thousand dollars ($30,000).

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Payment Method and Timing
provisions.summary: Defendant must make the penalty payment on the date of entry of the consent decree by certified or cashier's check.

requirements.description: Make payment by certified or cashier's check on date of entry
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant shall make the payment required by Paragraph 9 on the date of entry of this Consent Decree by certified or cashier's check made payable to the Treasurer of the United States and delivered to: the Office of Consumer Litigation, Civil Division, U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, D.C. 20530, for appropriate disposition.

provisions.title: Default in Payment
provisions.summary: If defendant defaults on payment for more than ten days, the entire unpaid penalty plus interest becomes immediately due and payable.

requirements.description: Pay entire unpaid penalty plus interest if default continues for 10 days beyond due date
requirements.quoted_text: In the event of any default in payment, which default continues for ten (10) days beyond the due date of payment, the entire unpaid penalty, together with interest, as computed pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1961, from the date of default to the date of payment, shall immediately become due and payable.

provisions.title: Deletion of Unlawfully Collected Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must delete all personal information collected from children without parental authorization through its websites from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry of the consent decree.

requirements.description: Delete all personal information collected from children without parental authorization
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant, and its successors and assigns, within ten (10) days of the date of entry of this Consent Decree, shall delete all personal information collected from children without their parent's authorization through www.lisafrank.com and shop.lisafrank.com at any time from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry of this Consent Decree.

provisions.title: Distribution of Consent Decree and Compliance Guide to Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Within 30 days, defendant must provide a copy of the consent decree and FTC compliance guide to current principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees, secure signed acknowledgments, and report compliance to the Commission within 10 days thereafter.

requirements.description: Provide consent decree and compliance guide to current personnel and secure signed acknowledgments
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant, and its successors and assigns, within thirty (30) days of the date of entry of this Consent Decree, shall provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the Federal Trade Commission compliance guide entitled How to Comply with the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (Nov. 1999) ("compliance guide") (attached hereto as "Appendix B") to each of its current principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys having responsibilities related to the subject matter of this Consent Decree, secure from each such person a signed statement acknowledging receipt of a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide

requirements.description: Submit signed statement to Commission confirming compliance with distribution requirement
requirements.quoted_text: shall, within ten (10) days of complying with this paragraph, submit to the Commission a signed statement setting forth the fact and manner of defendant's compliance, including the name and title of each person to whom a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide has been provided.

provisions.title: Distribution of Consent Decree and Compliance Guide to Future Personnel
provisions.summary: For three years after entry, defendant must provide a copy of the consent decree and compliance guide to future principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees within 30 days of their assuming such positions, secure signed acknowledgments, and maintain these records.

requirements.description: Provide consent decree and compliance guide to future personnel within 30 days of assuming position
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant, and its successors and assigns, shall, for a period of three (3) years after the entry of this Consent Decree, provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide to each of its future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all future employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys having responsibilities related to the subject matter of this Consent Decree, and secure from each such person a signed and dated statement acknowledging receipt of a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide, within thirty (30) days after the person assumes such position or responsibilities.

requirements.description: Maintain copies of signed statements and make available to FTC upon request
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant shall maintain copies of the signed statements, as well as other information regarding the fact and manner of its compliance, including the name and title of each person to whom a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide has been provided and, upon request, shall make the statements and other information available to the Federal Trade Commission.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting to FTC
provisions.summary: Defendant must file detailed written compliance reports with the Commission within 120 days after entry and at such other times as the FTC may require.

requirements.description: File written compliance report detailing privacy notices,collection practices, parental consent methods, security procedures, and other compliance measures
requirements.quoted_text: Within one hundred and twenty (120) days after entry of this Consent Decree, and at such other times as the Federal Trade Commission may require, defendant, and its successors and assigns, shall file with the Commission a written report, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which it has complied and is complying with this Consent Decree. This report shall include but not be limited to: a. a copy of each different privacy notice on any of its websites that are subject to the Rule; b. a statement setting forth in detail each place where the privacy notice on the website is located and a copy of each screen or page on which the website collects personal information; c. a copy of each different privacy notice to parents; d. a statement setting forth in detail when and how notices to parents are provided; e. a statement setting forth in detail the methods used to obtain verifiable parental consent prior to any collection, use, and/or disclosure of personal information from children; f. a statement setting forth in detail the means provided for parents to review the personal information collected from their children and to refuse to permit its further use or maintenance; g. a statement setting forth in detail why each type of information collected is reasonably necessary for the provision of the particular related activity; and h. a statement setting forth in detail the procedures used to protect the confidentiality, security, and integrity of personal information collected from children.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping and Document Production
provisions.summary: For five years after entry, defendant must maintain and make available to the FTC within 15 days of written request all documents demonstrating compliance, including web pages, forms, and representations regarding collection practices.

requirements.description: Maintain and produce compliance documents to FTC within 15 days of written request
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant, and its successors and assigns, shall, for a period of five (5) years after entry of this Consent Decree, maintain and make available to the Federal Trade Commission for inspection and copying within fifteen (15) days of the date of receipt of a written request, a print or electronic copy in HTML format of all documents demonstrating compliance with the terms and provisions of this Consent Decree, including, but not limited to, a sample copy of every information collection form, web page, or screen, and a sample copy of each document containing any representation regarding defendant's collection, use, and disclosure practices pertaining to personal information.

provisions.title: Notification of Business Changes
provisions.summary: Defendant must notify the Commission at least 30 days prior to any business change that may affect compliance obligations, including mergers, dissolutions, sales, bankruptcy, or corporate name or address changes.

requirements.description: Notify Commission 30 days prior to business changes affecting compliance
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant Lisa Frank, Inc., and its successors and assigns, shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in its business that may affect compliance obligations arising under this Consent Decree, including, but not limited to, any merger, incorporation, dissolution, assignment, sale or other action that would result in the emergence of a successor corporation; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate; the proposed filing of a bankruptcy petition; or a change in the corporate name or address.

requirements.description: Notify Commission as soon as practicable if learning of change less than 30 days prior
requirements.quoted_text: Provided, however, that with respect to any proposed change in the corporation about which defendant, its successors and assigns, learns less than thirty (30) days prior to the date such action is to take place, it shall notify the Commission as soon as is practicable after obtaining such knowledge.

provisions.title: Taxpayer Identification Number Disclosure
provisions.summary: Defendant must furnish its taxpayer identification number to the FTC for purposes of collecting and reporting on any delinquent amounts.

requirements.description: Furnish taxpayer identifying number to the FTC
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant Lisa Frank, Inc. is hereby required, in accordance with 31 U.S.C. § 7701, to furnish to the Federal Trade Commission its taxpayer identifying number (social security number or employer identification number), which shall be used for purposes of collecting and reporting on any delinquent amount arising out of its relationship with the government.

provisions.title: Continuing Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction to enforce, interpret, modify, or punish violations of the consent decree.

requirements.description: Court retains continuing jurisdiction over the matter
requirements.quoted_text: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of enabling any of the parties to this Consent Decree to apply to the Court at any time for such further orders or directives as may be necessary or appropriate for the interpretation or modification of this Consent Decree, for the enforcement of compliance therewith, or for the punishment of violations thereof.

duration.termination_text: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of enabling any of the parties to this Consent Decree to apply to the Court at any time for such further orders or directives as may be necessary or appropriate for the interpretation or modification of this Consent Decree, for the enforcement of compliance therewith, or for the punishment of violations thereof.
